The Department of Military
Science and Tactics has been fortunate enough to procure the
services of an army man who is
now serving his eighth enlistment
period; having, indeed, been in the
army since June 21, 1898. First
Sergeant William J. Flemming
has a record that indicates that
he should be of very great value
in his new station at Hopkins as
an assistant to Captain Ellis. He
has served in the Spanish-American War, and with the Luzon Expedition in the Philippines, is an
expert rifleman, and knows all
there is to be known about infantry work. Sergeant Flemming's
home town is Pittsfield, Mass.
An additional commissioned
officer will probably be sent to
Hopkins next fall, although the
matter is still somewhat uncertain. Besides increased personnel, additional equipment has arrived, and even more is to come.
The cadet officers have been issued
holsters and belts which make
their appearance at drill very
"natty" indeed but the most notable acquisition is that of two
machine guns which arrived not
long ago. Captain Ellis intends
to form a machine gun squad from
members of the freshman and
sophomore companies, and hereafter machine gun work will be a
part of every man's military education at Hopkins.
Next year, the unit will use the
1903 model army rifle, instead of
the present 1917 design. The
older model is much superior in
shooting qualities, and the unit
will profit by the transaction when
they receive the 190 guns promised for next fall.
Colonel Bull's inspection of the
unit resulted in its recommendation for inspection by the inspectors of distinguished institutions.

Colonel Bull. Upon their decision rests the question of whether
or not Johns Hopkins will be a
distinguished institution this
year. Every effort is being made
to make the result of the second
inspection favorable, and to this
end Captain Ellis has decided to

inspection. The plan is a good
one, and has been made even more

interests of athletics at the University, the Johns Hopkins 'Varsity Club has taken several important steps during the past few
Permission has• been
weeks.

conduct a campaign to raise the

of a company known as the 'Varsity Holding Company, the purpose of which will be to take over

interests of the General Athletic
Association. This organization
will be governed by a board of
trustees, consisting of nine men;
two of whom shall be students
at the University, elected by the
undergraduate body. Under this
system, the athletic association at
the University will continue to
perform its duties as usual, except that it will be relieved of the
large and important task of handling the finances. All such matters as the collecting of athletic
fees, and the management of ticket sales will be left in the hands
of the Holding Company, thus
leaving the General Athletic Association free to concentrate on
the actual building up of the
teajns and arranging the games.
Aiming to bring about still
greater co-operation between the
'Varsity Club and the active student body, the requirements for
membership to the club have been
broadened to include undergraduates. This means that any man
who has won an "H" will be eligible to become a member of the
'Varsity Club. In this way, it is
hoped to bring the club into closer
touch with the activities which are
going on at Homewood, and to give
the students, who are taking an
active part in athletics, and who
are therefore intimately in touch
with the present situation at Hopkins, an opportunity to express
their view.

The memorial meeting in honor
of Sir William Osier, held last
Wednesday, was a true expression
of the appreciation which Baltimoreans have for, the services rendered by that eminent physician.
The Civil Engineering Hall was
filled to its utmost capacity by his
friends and admirers, anxious to
pay tribute to his memory.
President Goodnow, who presided, opened the meeting with a few
remarks on the broad sympathies
and generosity of Dr. Osier, and
his unfailing interest in Hopkins.
He then introduced Dr. William
H. Welch, who was associated
with Dr. Osier during the entire
time that he was in charge of the
medical school.
Dr. Welch confined his address
to a brief description of Osler's
medical career, and paid a splendid tribute to his accomplishments
and his virtues, both as a surgeon
and as a man. He said it was not
due to his position as an author,
a scientist or a teacher that his
fame would live, but to a combination of all of these:
"It was Osler's genius for organization that gave to the student attending the Johns Hopkins
Medical School opportunities unequaled anywhere in America. He
did not attempt to impart the entire contents of a book, but
specialized on certain diseases.
The result was that he placed the
young doctor in a position to go
on with his specialty the rest of
his life. He taught from the
standpoint of a naturalist, being
interested in the natural history
of diseases. He made 'the student
intensely interested in the available knowledge of medicine, by
not teaching as though that knowledge were already known.
"It is impossible at this time
to estimate the exact value of his
contributions, because they are so
numerous and- cover such a wide
range of subjects."

It is with a feeling of sincere
regret and discouragement that
THE NEWS-LETTER looks back on
the first and most important two
weeks of the season-ticket campaign. Not only has the expected amount not been raised, but
the expenses of the campaign have
scarcely 'been met by the proceeds
of the tickets sold.
Why has this campaign failed
so miserably? There can be but
one cause, and hard as it may be
to face, we must do so.
It is the deplorable lack of pep
and spirit which Johns Hopkins
students have shown the past few
years, this quagmire in which they
are wallowing, and out of which
they seem not only uhable, but unwilling to climb.
How many of you, out of an undergraduate student body numbering about 600, have put yourselves out to the extent of spending even half an hour in the Barn,
folding or addressing circulars?
Not more than 75. How many of
you have obtained even one subscription? Not more than 50. A
perfect example of the all-consuming lethargy which is eating away
at the vitals of Johns Hopkins
spirit.
Let us look into this matter
and see who have been doing all
the work which has been required
to obtain the results so far netted.
With but few exceptions, all who
have done any work for this campaign are the men on the athletic
squads, or those who are in some
way connected with them. Those
who are not connected with the
teams have not so much as lifted
a finger to aid Mr. Kistler in the

splendid work which he is inaugurating this spring.
How many of you, who have not
helped in this cause, may we take
the liberty of asking, whether
sophomore, junior or senior, have,
since the lifting of your freshman
regulations requiring you to attend Hopkins games seen as many
as three contests at Homewood?
If you are one of these slackers,
we are talking straight to you.
What is the matter with you?
Haven't you the backbone to come
out and sacrifice a little of your
highly valuable time, or are you
content to take everything from
and give nothing to your University? If you are among this class,
you should be ashamed to call
yourself a Hopkins man, for Hopkins is frankly ashamed to claim
you.
This spring, the athletic managements have offered to us the
greatest opportunity in the athletic line since Hopkins has been
founded. Not only have the largest schedules on record been undertaken, but colleges and universities which have.hitherto been
considered out of • our class, will
be met this season.
Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell—all have been included in
baseball, track and lacrosse. No
college is too good for our Alma
Mater. Do we ralize that?( What
does it entail on our part? Are we
to sit quietly by while these colleges come down,trounce us,and go
-home again? If we do this, it is a
foregone conclusion that there will
not be a game with Hopkins on
their next year's schedule. But
Hopkins is on these schedules to
stay, and the only way for this to
be accomplished is for each and
every one of us to do his part.
We can serve our Alma Mater
in more ways than one. If we are
athletically inclined, we owe it to
ourselves as well as to the College
to go out for some team. If we
are physically unableto participate
actively, there are many vacancies
in the managerial departments
open to any candidate. And last,
but far from least, we can serve
our College in the grandstand,
backing up her every play with
cheers and songs. The first game
is this Friday, against Princeton
in baseball. With such a curtain
raiser to our athletic program it
is to be hoped that every Hopkins
man who does not participate actively in the contest in some way,
will be in the rooting section,
cheering on the Black and Blue.
Is it worth while for us to keep
these big colleges on our schedule?
If it is, it is the plain duty of
every true Hopkins man to be in
the stands, not only Friday, but
Saturday, and eyery day on which
a game is called.
Beauty used to be a matter of
line and form; now it's a matter
of concealing the ears, arching the
eyebrows, redding up the lips and
giving the neck and back more
air.

An Excellent Idea.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Along with the immediate
impetus of the many non-athletic
activities at Hopkins, has come a
stampede to draw up constitutions and to bestow insignia.
Every small organization in the
College is at present designing
badges for its officers or members.
While the idea of giving a sign of
recognition to men who have excelled in student pursuits is a
very worthy one, it seems to the
writer, that before we create a
whole string of diversified cheap
jewelry with which to decorate
our persons like German generals,
we should consider if it would not
be better to adopt a uniform Hopkins badge for all these activities.
The badge or pendant might be of
gold in the form of the shield of
our University, and might be engraved with the name of the field
or fields of endeavor in which it
was won. It might in addition
bear a star on its border for each
activity of its wearer.
The arguments for this are obvious. An emblem of the kind
would be distinctive of Hopkins;
a suitable and valued award for
services, and a suitable of worth
for a multitude of small trinkets.
The suggestion is being taken up
with the Student Council. Will
THE NEWS-LETTER co-operate in
trying to secure its adoption with
the various activities?
The Student Council, or a commission appointed by them, and
including representatives from the
several activities might decide on
the badge and designate the services for which it could be awarded.
Yours,
JOHN H. LEWIN.

It is with a feeling of sincere
regret and discouragement that
THE NEWS-LETTER looks back on
the first and most important two
weeks of the season-ticket campaign. Not only has the expected amount not been raised, but
the expenses of the campaign have
scarcely 'been met by the proceeds
of the tickets sold.
Why has this campaign failed
so miserably? There can be but
one cause, and hard as it may be
to face, we must do so.
It is the deplorable lack of pep
and spirit which Johns Hopkins
students have shown the past few
years, this quagmire in which they
are wallowing, and out of which
they seem not only uhable, but unwilling to climb.
How many of you, out of an undergraduate student body numbering about 600, have put yourselves out to the extent of spending even half an hour in the Barn,
folding or addressing circulars?
Not more than 75. How many of
you have obtained even one subscription? Not more than 50. A
perfect example of the all-consuming lethargy which is eating away
at the vitals of Johns Hopkins
spirit.
Let us look into this matter
and see who have been doing all
the work which has been required
to obtain the results so far netted.
With but few exceptions, all who
have done any work for this campaign are the men on the athletic
squads, or those who are in some
way connected with them. Those
who are not connected with the
teams have not so much as lifted
a finger to aid Mr. Kistler in the

splendid work which he is inaugurating this spring.
How many of you, who have not
helped in this cause, may we take
the liberty of asking, whether
sophomore, junior or senior, have,
since the lifting of your freshman
regulations requiring you to attend Hopkins games seen as many
as three contests at Homewood?
If you are one of these slackers,
we are talking straight to you.
What is the matter with you?
Haven't you the backbone to come
out and sacrifice a little of your
highly valuable time, or are you
content to take everything from
and give nothing to your University? If you are among this class,
you should be ashamed to call
yourself a Hopkins man, for Hopkins is frankly ashamed to claim
you.
This spring, the athletic managements have offered to us the
greatest opportunity in the athletic line since Hopkins has been
founded. Not only have the largest schedules on record been undertaken, but colleges and universities which have.hitherto been
considered out of • our class, will
be met this season.
Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Cornell—all have been included in
baseball, track and lacrosse. No
college is too good for our Alma
Mater. Do we ralize that?( What
does it entail on our part? Are we
to sit quietly by while these colleges come down,trounce us,and go
-home again? If we do this, it is a
foregone conclusion that there will
not be a game with Hopkins on
their next year's schedule. But
Hopkins is on these schedules to
stay, and the only way for this to
be accomplished is for each and
every one of us to do his part.
We can serve our Alma Mater
in more ways than one. If we are
athletically inclined, we owe it to
ourselves as well as to the College
to go out for some team. If we
are physically unableto participate
actively, there are many vacancies
in the managerial departments
open to any candidate. And last,
but far from least, we can serve
our College in the grandstand,
backing up her every play with
cheers and songs. The first game
is this Friday, against Princeton
in baseball. With such a curtain
raiser to our athletic program it
is to be hoped that every Hopkins
man who does not participate actively in the contest in some way,
will be in the rooting section,
cheering on the Black and Blue.
Is it worth while for us to keep
these big colleges on our schedule?
If it is, it is the plain duty of
every true Hopkins man to be in
the stands, not only Friday, but
Saturday, and eyery day on which
a game is called.
Beauty used to be a matter of
line and form; now it's a matter
of concealing the ears, arching the
eyebrows, redding up the lips and
giving the neck and back more
air.

the rehabilitation of Palestine;

refuge for oppressed Jews living

where religious persecution still
prevails. For this reason, no Jew
can consistently refuse to subscribe to the Palestine Restoration Fund.
